new.ruleText: new_start Normally, all new_end instances of X on an object have the same value at any given time. new_start If an object gains an ability, the value of X within that ability is the value defined by that ability, or 0 if that ability doesn’t define a value of X. new_end

old.ruleText: old_start All old_end instances of X on an object have the same value at any given time.

new.ruleText: A spell or ability that creates a token sets both its name and its new_start subtype. new_end If the spell or ability doesn’t specify the name of the token, its name is the same as its new_start subtype(s). new_end A “Goblin Scout creature token,” for example, is named “Goblin Scout” and has the creature subtypes Goblin and Scout. Once a token is on the battlefield, changing its name doesn’t change its new_start subtype, new_end and vice versa.

old.ruleText: A spell or ability that creates a old_start creature old_end token sets both its name and its old_start creature type. old_end If the spell or ability doesn’t specify the name of the old_start creature old_end token, its name is the same as its old_start creature type(s). old_end A “Goblin Scout creature token,” for example, is named “Goblin Scout” and has the creature subtypes Goblin and Scout. Once a token is on the battlefield, changing its name doesn’t change its old_start creature type, old_end and vice versa.

new.ruleText: An ability whose cost or effect specifies that it moves the object it’s on out of a particular zone functions only in that zone, unless that ability’s trigger condition, or a previous part of that ability’s cost or effect, specifies that the object is put into that zone. new_start The same is true if the effect of that ability creates a delayed triggered ability whose effect moves the object out of a particular zone. new_end

old.ruleText: An ability whose cost or effect specifies that it moves the object it’s on out of a particular zone functions only in that zone, unless that ability’s trigger condition, or a previous part of that ability’s cost or effect, specifies that the object is put into that zone.

new.ruleText: Some spells and abilities refer to counters being “placed” on an object. This refers to putting counters on that object while it’s on the battlefield and also to an object new_start that’s given counters as it enters new_end the new_start battlefield. new_end

old.ruleText: Some spells and abilities refer to counters being “placed” on an object. This refers to putting counters on that object while it’s on the battlefield and also to an object old_start entering old_end the old_start battlefield with counters on it as a result of a replacement effect (see rule 614.1c). old_end

new.ruleText: The converted mana cost of an object with no mana cost is new_start 0, unless that object is the back face of a double–faced permanent. new_end

old.ruleText: The converted mana cost of an object with no mana cost is old_start 0. old_end

new.ruleText: The converted mana cost of a double–faced permanent’s back face is calculated as though it had the mana cost of its front face. This is a change from previous rules. If a permanent is a copy of the back face of a double–faced card (even if the card representing that copy is itself a double–faced card), the converted mana cost of that permanent is 0.

Artifacts have their own unique set of subtypes; these subtypes are called artifact types. The artifact types are new_start Clue, new_end Contraption, Equipment (see rule 301.5), and Fortification (see rule 301.6).

old.ruleText: Artifacts have their own unique set of subtypes; these subtypes are called artifact types. The artifact types are Contraption, Equipment (see rule 301.5), and Fortification (see rule 301.6).

new.ruleText: Planeswalkers have their own unique set of subtypes; these subtypes are called planeswalker types. The planeswalker types are Ajani, new_start Arlinn, new_end Ashiok, Bolas, Chandra, Dack, Daretti, Domri, Elspeth, Freyalise, Garruk, Gideon, Jace, Karn, Kiora, Koth, Liliana, Nahiri, Narset, Nissa, Nixilis, Ral, Sarkhan, Sorin, Tamiyo, Teferi, Tezzeret, Tibalt, Ugin, Venser, Vraska, and Xenagos. If a player controls two or more planeswalkers that share a planeswalker type, that player chooses one of them, and the rest are put into their owners’ graveyards. This “planeswalker uniqueness rule” is a state–based action. See rule 704.

old.ruleText: Planeswalkers have their own unique set of subtypes; these subtypes are called planeswalker types. The planeswalker types are Ajani, Ashiok, Bolas, Chandra, Dack, Daretti, Domri, Elspeth, Freyalise, Garruk, Gideon, Jace, Karn, Kiora, Koth, Liliana, Nahiri, Narset, Nissa, Nixilis, Ral, Sarkhan, Sorin, Tamiyo, Teferi, Tezzeret, Tibalt, Ugin, Venser, Vraska, and Xenagos. If a player controls two or more planeswalkers that share a planeswalker type, that player chooses one of them, and the rest are put into their owners’ graveyards. This “planeswalker uniqueness rule” is a state–based action. See rule 704.

new.ruleText: Creatures and tribals share their lists of subtypes; these subtypes are called creature types. The creature types are Advisor, Ally, Angel, Antelope, Ape, Archer, Archon, Artificer, Assassin, Assembly–Worker, Atog, Aurochs, Avatar, Badger, Barbarian, Basilisk, Bat, Bear, Beast, Beeble, Berserker, Bird, Blinkmoth, Boar, Bringer, Brushwagg, Camarid, Camel, Caribou, Carrier, Cat, Centaur, Cephalid, Chimera, Citizen, Cleric, Cockatrice, Construct, Coward, Crab, Crocodile, Cyclops, Dauthi, Demon, Deserter, Devil, Djinn, Dragon, Drake, Dreadnought, Drone, Druid, Dryad, Dwarf, Efreet, Elder, Eldrazi, Elemental, Elephant, Elf, Elk, Eye, Faerie, Ferret, Fish, Flagbearer, Fox, Frog, Fungus, Gargoyle, Germ, Giant, Gnome, Goat, Goblin, God, Golem, Gorgon, Graveborn, Gremlin, Griffin, Hag, Harpy, Hellion, Hippo, Hippogriff, Homarid, Homunculus, Horror, Horse, Hound, Human, Hydra, Hyena, Illusion, Imp, Incarnation, Insect, Jellyfish, Juggernaut, Kavu, Kirin, Kithkin, Knight, Kobold, Kor, Kraken, Lamia, Lammasu, Leech, Leviathan, Lhurgoyf, Licid, Lizard, Manticore, Masticore, Mercenary, Merfolk, Metathran, Minion, Minotaur, new_start Mole, new_end Monger, Mongoose, Monk, Moonfolk, Mutant, Myr, Mystic, Naga, Nautilus, Nephilim, Nightmare, Nightstalker, Ninja, Noggle, Nomad, Nymph, Octopus, Ogre, Ooze, Orb, Orc, Orgg, Ouphe, Ox, Oyster, Pegasus, Pentavite, Pest, Phelddagrif, Phoenix, Pincher, Pirate, Plant, Praetor, Prism, Processor, Rabbit, Rat, Rebel, Reflection, Rhino, Rigger, Rogue, Sable, Salamander, Samurai, Sand, Saproling, Satyr, Scarecrow, Scion, Scorpion, Scout, Serf, Serpent, Shade, Shaman, Shapeshifter, Sheep, Siren, Skeleton, Slith, Sliver, Slug, Snake, Soldier, Soltari, Spawn, Specter, Spellshaper, Sphinx, Spider, Spike, Spirit, Splinter, Sponge, Squid, Squirrel, Starfish, Surrakar, Survivor, Tetravite, Thalakos, Thopter, Thrull, Treefolk, Triskelavite, Troll, Turtle, Unicorn, Vampire, Vedalken, Viashino, Volver, Wall, Warrior, Weird, Werewolf, Whale, Wizard, Wolf, Wolverine, Wombat, Worm, Wraith, Wurm, Yeti, Zombie, and Zubera.

old.ruleText: Creatures and tribals share their lists of subtypes; these subtypes are called creature types. The creature types are Advisor, Ally, Angel, Antelope, Ape, Archer, Archon, Artificer, Assassin, Assembly–Worker, Atog, Aurochs, Avatar, Badger, Barbarian, Basilisk, Bat, Bear, Beast, Beeble, Berserker, Bird, Blinkmoth, Boar, Bringer, Brushwagg, Camarid, Camel, Caribou, Carrier, Cat, Centaur, Cephalid, Chimera, Citizen, Cleric, Cockatrice, Construct, Coward, Crab, Crocodile, Cyclops, Dauthi, Demon, Deserter, Devil, Djinn, Dragon, Drake, Dreadnought, Drone, Druid, Dryad, Dwarf, Efreet, Elder, Eldrazi, Elemental, Elephant, Elf, Elk, Eye, Faerie, Ferret, Fish, Flagbearer, Fox, Frog, Fungus, Gargoyle, Germ, Giant, Gnome, Goat, Goblin, God, Golem, Gorgon, Graveborn, Gremlin, Griffin, Hag, Harpy, Hellion, Hippo, Hippogriff, Homarid, Homunculus, Horror, Horse, Hound, Human, Hydra, Hyena, Illusion, Imp, Incarnation, Insect, Jellyfish, Juggernaut, Kavu, Kirin, Kithkin, Knight, Kobold, Kor, Kraken, Lamia, Lammasu, Leech, Leviathan, Lhurgoyf, Licid, Lizard, Manticore, Masticore, Mercenary, Merfolk, Metathran, Minion, Minotaur, Monger, Mongoose, Monk, Moonfolk, Mutant, Myr, Mystic, Naga, Nautilus, Nephilim, Nightmare, Nightstalker, Ninja, Noggle, Nomad, Nymph, Octopus, Ogre, Ooze, Orb, Orc, Orgg, Ouphe, Ox, Oyster, Pegasus, Pentavite, Pest, Phelddagrif, Phoenix, Pincher, Pirate, Plant, Praetor, Prism, Processor, Rabbit, Rat, Rebel, Reflection, Rhino, Rigger, Rogue, Sable, Salamander, Samurai, Sand, Saproling, Satyr, Scarecrow, Scion, Scorpion, Scout, Serf, Serpent, Shade, Shaman, Shapeshifter, Sheep, Siren, Skeleton, Slith, Sliver, Slug, Snake, Soldier, Soltari, Spawn, Specter, Spellshaper, Sphinx, Spider, Spike, Spirit, Splinter, Sponge, Squid, Squirrel, Starfish, Surrakar, Survivor, Tetravite, Thalakos, Thopter, Thrull, Treefolk, Triskelavite, Troll, Turtle, Unicorn, Vampire, Vedalken, Viashino, Volver, Wall, Warrior, Weird, Werewolf, Whale, Wizard, Wolf, Wolverine, Wombat, Worm, Wraith, Wurm, Yeti, Zombie, and Zubera.

new.ruleText: An ability word appears in italics at the beginning of some abilities. Ability words are similar to keywords in that they tie together cards that have similar functionality, but they have no special rules meaning and no individual entries in the Comprehensive Rules. The ability words are battalion, bloodrush, channel, chroma, cohort, constellation, converge, new_start delirium, new_end domain, fateful hour, ferocious, formidable, grandeur, hellbent, heroic, imprint, inspired, join forces, kinship, landfall, lieutenant, metalcraft, morbid, parley, radiance, raid, rally, spell mastery, strive, sweep, tempting offer, threshold, and will of the council.

old.ruleText: An ability word appears in italics at the beginning of some abilities. Ability words are similar to keywords in that they tie together cards that have similar functionality, but they have no special rules meaning and no individual entries in the Comprehensive Rules. The ability words are battalion, bloodrush, channel, chroma, cohort, constellation, converge, domain, fateful hour, ferocious, formidable, grandeur, hellbent, heroic, imprint, inspired, join forces, kinship, landfall, lieutenant, metalcraft, morbid, parley, radiance, raid, rally, spell mastery, strive, sweep, tempting offer, threshold, and will of the council.

new.ruleText: An object that moves from one zone to another becomes a new object with no memory of, or relation to, its previous existence. There are new_start eight new_end exceptions to this rule:

old.ruleText: An object that moves from one zone to another becomes a new object with no memory of, or relation to, its previous existence. There are old_start seven old_end exceptions to this rule:

new.ruleText: new_start If an effect allows a nonland card to be cast, other parts of that effect new_end can new_start find the new new_end object that new_start card becomes after it moves new_end to new_start the stack as a result of new_end being cast new_start this way. new_end

old.ruleText: old_start A resolving spell or activated ability old_end can old_start perform actions on an old_end object that old_start moved from one zone old_end to old_start another while that spell was old_end being cast old_start or that ability was being activated, if that object moved to a public zone. old_end

new.ruleText: If an effect causes an object to move to a public zone, other parts of that effect can find that object. If the cost of a spell or ability causes an object to move to a public zone, that spell or ability’s effects can find that object.

Second, all combat damage that’s been assigned is dealt simultaneously. This turn–based action doesn’t use the stack. No player has the chance to cast spells or activate abilities between the time combat damage is assigned and the time it’s dealt.

old.ruleText: Second, all combat damage that’s been assigned is dealt simultaneously. This turn–based action doesn’t use the stack. No player has the chance to cast spells or activate abilities between the time combat damage is assigned and the time it’s dealt. old_start This is a change from previous rules. old_end

new.ruleText: To transform a permanent, turn it over so that its other face is up. new_start Only permanents represented by double–faced cards can transform. (See rule 711, “Double–Faced Cards.”) new_end

old.ruleText: To transform a permanent, turn it over so that its other face is up.

new.ruleText: If a spell or ability instructs a player to transform a permanent that isn’t represented by a double–faced card, nothing happens.
If a spell or ability instructs a player to transform a permanent, and the face that permanent would transform into is represented by an instant or sorcery card face, nothing happens.

Some triggered abilities trigger when an object “transforms into” an object new_start with a specified characteristic. new_end Such an ability triggers if new_start the new_end object new_start transforms and has new_end the specified new_start characteristic new_end immediately after new_start it transforms. new_end

old.ruleText: Some triggered abilities trigger when an object “transforms into” an object old_start identified by name. old_end Such an ability triggers old_start only old_end if old_start that old_end object old_start didn’t have old_end the specified old_start name immediately before the transform instruction and does have the specified name old_end immediately after old_start the transform instruction. old_end

new.ruleText: If an activated or triggered ability of a permanent that isn’t a delayed triggered ability of that permanent tries to transform it, the permanent transforms only if it hasn’t transformed since the ability was put onto the stack. If a delayed triggered ability of a permanent tries to transform that permanent, the permanent transforms only if it hasn’t transformed since that delayed triggered ability was created. In either case, if the permanent has already transformed, the instruction to transform is ignored. This is a change from previous rules.
“Investigate” means “Put a colorless Clue artifact token onto the battlefield. It has ‘{2}, Sacrifice this artifact: Draw a card.’”
If multiple sources with lifelink deal damage at the same time, they cause separate life gain events (see rule 118.9).

Madness is a keyword that represents two abilities. The first is a static ability that functions while the card with madness is in a player’s hand. The second is a triggered ability that functions when the first ability is applied. “Madness [cost]” means “If a player would discard this card, that player discards it, but new_start exiles new_end it instead of putting it into his or her graveyard” and “When this card is exiled this way, its owner may cast it by paying [cost] rather than paying its mana cost. If that player doesn’t, he or she puts this card into his or her graveyard.”

old.ruleText: Madness is a keyword that represents two abilities. The first is a static ability that functions while the card with madness is in a player’s hand. The second is a triggered ability that functions when the first ability is applied. “Madness [cost]” means “If a player would discard this card, that player discards it, but old_start may exile old_end it instead of putting it into his or her graveyard” and “When this card is exiled this way, its owner may cast it by paying [cost] rather than paying its mana cost. If that player doesn’t, he or she puts this card into his or her graveyard.”

new.ruleText: Skulk is an evasion ability.
A creature with skulk can’t be blocked by creatures with greater power. (See rule 509, “Declare Blockers Step.”)
Multiple instances of skulk on the same creature are redundant.

A double–faced card has a Magic card face on each side rather than a Magic card face on one side and a Magic card back on the other. Each face may have abilities that allow the new_start card new_end to “transform,” or turn over to its other face. Tokens and cards with a Magic card back can’t transform. (See rule 701.25, “Transform.”)

old.ruleText: A double–faced card has a Magic card face on each side rather than a Magic card face on one side and a Magic card back on the other. Each face may have abilities that allow the old_start permanent old_end to “transform,” or turn over to its other face. Tokens and cards with a Magic card back can’t transform. (See rule 701.25, “Transform.”)

new.ruleText: A double–faced card’s front face new_start is marked by a front–face symbol in new_end its new_start upper left corner. On cards in the Innistrad block and Shadows over Innistrad set, the front–face symbol is a sun. On Magic Origins double–faced cards, the front–face symbol is a modified Planeswalker icon. new_end

old.ruleText: A double–faced card’s front face old_start includes old_end its old_start mana cost. Its back face has no mana cost. old_end

new.ruleText: new_start A double–faced card’s back new_end face new_start is marked by new_end a new_start back–face symbol new_end in its upper left new_start corner. On cards in the Innistrad block and Shadows over Innistrad set, the back–face symbol is new_end a new_start crescent moon. On Magic Origins double–faced cards, the back–face symbol is new_end a new_start full new_end Planeswalker new_start icon. new_end

old.ruleText: old_start Each old_end face old_start of old_end a old_start double–faced card has an icon old_end in its upper left old_start corner (for example, old_end a old_start sun or old_end a old_start stylized old_end Planeswalker old_start symbol). These icons have no effect on game play. old_end

new.ruleText: While a double–faced permanent’s back face is up, it has only the characteristics of its back face. new_start However, its converted mana cost is calculated using the mana cost of its front face. This is a change from previous rules. If a permanent is copying the new_end back face new_start of new_end a new_start double–faced card (even if the card representing that copy is itself a double–faced card), the converted new_end mana new_start cost of that permanent is 0. new_end

old.ruleText: While a double–faced permanent’s back face is up, it has only the characteristics of its back face. old_start The old_end back face old_start doesn’t have old_end a mana old_start cost; it has the colors in its color indicator (see rule 202.2e), if any. old_end

new.ruleText: If a spell or ability instructs a player to transform a permanent, and the face that permanent would transform into is represented by an instant or sorcery card face, nothing happens.
If a player is instructed to put a card that isn’t a double–faced card onto the battlefield transformed, that card stays in its current zone. This is a change from previous rules.
